SUMMER by [Edith Wharton]63-edith wharton 1917 [I]0-i [A girl]144-a girl came out of [[lawyer Royall]64-mr. royall 's house]145-lawyer royall 's house , at the end of [the one street of North Dormer]146-the one street of north dormer , and stood on the doorstep . It was the beginning of a June afternoon . The springlike transparent sky shed a rain of silver sunshine on [the roofs of [the village]148-the village]147-the roofs of the village , and on [the pastures and larchwoods surrounding [it]148-the village]149-the pastures and larchwoods surrounding it . A little wind moved among the round white clouds on the shoulders of [the hills]150-the hills , driving their shadows across [the fields]151-the fields and down [the grassy road]152-the grassy road that takes the name of [street]153-street when it passes through [North Dormer]1-north dormer . [The place]154-the place lies high and in the open , and lacks the lavish shade of [the more protected New England villages]155-the more protected new england villages . The clump of weeping - willows about [the duck pond]156-the duck pond , and the Norway spruces in front of the Hatchard gate , cast almost the only roadside shadow between [[lawyer Royall]64-mr. royall 's house]145-lawyer royall 's house and the point where , at [the other end of [the village]148-the village]158-the other end of the village , [the road]160-the road rises above [the church]161-the church and skirts the black hemlock wall enclosing [the cemetery]162-the cemetery . The little June wind , frisking down [the street]163-the street , shook the doleful fringes of the Hatchard spruces , caught the straw hat of [a young man just passing under them]164-a young man just passing under them , and spun it clean across [the road]160-the road into [the duck - pond]166-the duck - pond . As [he]164-a young man just passing under them ran to fish it out [the girl on [lawyer Royall]64-mr. royall 's doorstep]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep noticed that [he]164-a young man just passing under them was [a stranger]168-a stranger , that [he]164-a young man just passing under them wore city clothes , and that [he]164-a young man just passing under them was laughing with all [his]164-a young man just passing under them teeth , as [the young and careless]169-the young and careless laugh at such mishaps . [Her]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep heart contracted a little , and the shrinking that sometimes came over [her]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep when [she]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep saw [people with holiday faces]170-people with holiday faces made [her]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep draw back into [the house]171-the house and pretend to look for the key that [she]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep knew [she]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep had already put into [her]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep pocket . A narrow greenish mirror with a gilt eagle over it hung on the passage wall , and [she]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep looked critically at [her]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep reflection , wished for the thousandth time that [she]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep had blue eyes like [Annabel Balch]65-annabel balch , [the girl who sometimes came from [Springfield]2-springfield to spend a week with [old Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard]172-the girl who sometimes came from springfield to spend a week with old miss hatchard , straightened the sunburnt hat over [her]65-annabel balch small swarthy face , and turned out again into the sunshine . “ How [I]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep hate everything ! ”[167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep] [she]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep murmured . [The young man]173-the young man had passed through the Hatchard gate , and [she]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep had [the street]163-the street to [herself]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep . [North Dormer]1-north dormer is at all times [an empty place]175-an empty place , and at three o'clock on a June afternoon [its few able - bodied men]176-its few able - bodied men are off in [the fields]151-the fields or [woods]178-woods , and [the women indoors , engaged in languid household drudgery]179-the women indoors , engaged in languid household drudgery . [The girl]180-the girl walked along , swinging [her]180-the girl key on a finger , and looking about [her]180-the girl with the heightened attention produced by the presence of [a stranger]168-a stranger in [a familiar place]182-a familiar place . What , [she]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep wondered , did [North Dormer]1-north dormer look like to people from [other parts of [the world]184-the world]183-other parts of the world ? [She]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep [herself]167-the girl on lawyer royall 's doorstep had lived [there]185-there since the age of five , and had long supposed [it]185-there to be [a place of some importance]186-a place of some importance . But about a year before , [Mr. Miles]67-mr. miles , [the new Episcopal clergyman at [Hepburn]4-hepburn , who drove over every other Sunday -- when [the roads]188-the roads were not ploughed up by hauling -- to hold a service in [the North Dormer church]189-the north dormer church]187-the new episcopal clergyman at hepburn , who drove over every other sunday -- when the roads were not ploughed up by hauling -- to hold a service in the north dormer church , had proposed , in a fit of missionary zeal , to take [the young people]190-the young people down to [Nettleton]5-nettleton to hear an illustrated lecture on [the Holy Land]191-the holy land ; and [the dozen girls and boys who represented the future of [North Dormer]1-north dormer]192-the dozen girls and boys who represented the future of north dormer had been piled into [a farm - waggon]193-a farm - waggon , driven over [the hills]150-the hills to [Hepburn]4-hepburn , put into [a way - train]195-a way - train and carried to [Nettleton]5-nettleton . In the course of that incredible day [Charity Royall]69-charity had , for the first and only time , experienced railway - travel , looked into [shops]196-shops with plate - glass fronts , tasted cocoanut pie , sat in [a theatre]197-a theatre , and listened to [a gentleman]198-a gentleman saying unintelligible things before pictures that [she]69-charity would have enjoyed looking at if [his]198-a gentleman explanations had not prevented [her]69-charity from understanding them . This initiation had shown [her]69-charity that [North Dormer]1-north dormer was [a small place]199-a small place , and developed in [her]69-charity a thirst for information that [her]69-charity position as [custodian of [the village library]201-the village library]200-custodian of the village library had previously failed to excite . For a month or two [she]69-charity dipped feverishly and disconnectedly into the dusty volumes of [the Hatchard Memorial Library]202-the hatchard memorial library ; then the impression of [Nettleton]5-nettleton began to fade , and [she]69-charity found it easier to take [North Dormer]1-north dormer as the norm of [the universe]203-the universe than to go on reading . The sight of [the stranger]204-the stranger once more revived memories of [Nettleton]5-nettleton , and [North Dormer]1-north dormer shrank to its real size . As [she]69-charity looked up and down [it]1-north dormer , from [[lawyer Royall]64-mr. royall 's faded red house]205-lawyer royall 's faded red house at one end to [the white church]206-the white church at the other , [she]69-charity pitilessly took its measure . [There]185-there [it]185-there lay , [a weather - beaten sunburnt village of [the hills]150-the hills , abandoned of [men]210-men , left apart by [railway , trolley]211-railway , trolley , telegraph , and all the forces that link life to life in [modern communities]212-modern communities]208-a weather - beaten sunburnt village of the hills , abandoned of men , left apart by railway , trolley , telegraph , and all the forces that link life to life in modern communities . [It]185-there had [no shops]213-no shops , [no theatres]214-no theatres , [no lectures]215-no lectures , [no “ business block ”]1874-no “ business block ”[69-charity] ; only [a church that was opened every other Sunday if the state of [the roads]188-the roads]216-a church that was opened every other sunday if the state of the roads permitted , and [a library for which no new books had been bought for twenty years , and where the old ones mouldered undisturbed on the damp shelves]218-a library for which no new books had been bought for twenty years , and where the old ones mouldered undisturbed on the damp shelves . Yet [Charity Royall]69-charity had always been told that [she]69-charity ought to consider it a privilege that [her]69-charity lot had been cast in [North Dormer]1-north dormer . [She]69-charity knew that , compared to [the place [she]69-charity had come from]219-the place she had come from , [North Dormer]1-north dormer represented all the blessings of [the most refined civilization]220-the most refined civilization . [Everyone in [the village]148-the village]221-everyone in the village had told [her]69-charity so ever since [she]69-charity had been brought [there]185-there as [a child]224-a child . Even [old Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard had said to [her]69-charity , on a terrible occasion in [her]66-miss hatchard life : “ [[My]66-miss hatchard child]1875-my child , [you]69-charity must never cease to remember that it was [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall who brought [you]69-charity down from [the Mountain]8-the mountain . ”[66-miss hatchard] [She]69-charity had been “ brought down from [the Mountain ”]8-the mountain[69-charity] ; from the scarred cliff that lifted [its]1-north dormer sullen wall above [the lesser slopes of [Eagle Range]10-eagle range]225-the lesser slopes of eagle range , making a perpetual background of gloom to [the lonely valley]226-the lonely valley . [The Mountain]8-the mountain was a good fifteen miles away , but it rose so abruptly from [the lower hills]227-the lower hills that it seemed almost to cast its shadow over [North Dormer]1-north dormer . And it was like a great magnet drawing the clouds and scattering them in storm across [the valley]228-the valley . If ever , in the purest summer sky , there trailed a thread of vapour over [North Dormer]1-north dormer , it drifted to [the Mountain]8-the mountain as [a ship]229-a ship drifts to a whirlpool , and was caught among the rocks , torn up and multiplied , to sweep back over [the village]148-the village in rain and darkness . [Charity]69-charity was not very clear about [the Mountain]231-the mountain ; but [she]69-charity knew it was [a bad place]232-a bad place , and a shame to have come from , and that , whatever befell [her]69-charity in [North Dormer]1-north dormer , [she]69-charity ought , as [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard had once reminded [her]69-charity , to remember that [she]69-charity had been brought down from there , and hold [her]69-charity tongue and be thankful . [She]69-charity looked up at [the Mountain]8-the mountain , thinking of these things , and tried as usual to be thankful . But the sight of [the young man]173-the young man turning in at [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard 's gate had brought back the vision of [the glittering streets of [Nettleton]5-nettleton]234-the glittering streets of nettleton , and [she]69-charity felt ashamed of [her]69-charity old sun - hat , and sick of [North Dormer]1-north dormer , and jealously aware of [Annabel Balch]65-annabel balch of [Springfield]2-springfield , opening [her]65-annabel balch blue eyes somewhere far off on glories greater than the glories of [Nettleton]5-nettleton . “ How [I]69-charity hate everything ! ”[69-charity] [she]69-charity said again . Half way down [the street]163-the street [she]69-charity stopped at a weak - hinged gate . Passing through [it]236-it , [she]69-charity walked down [a brick path]237-a brick path to [a queer little brick temple with white wooden columns supporting a pediment on which was inscribed in tarnished gold letters : “ The Honorius Hatchard Memorial Library]1876-a queer little brick temple with white wooden columns supporting a pediment on which was inscribed in tarnished gold letters : “ the honorius hatchard memorial library , 1832 . ”[69-charity] [Honorius Hatchard]70-honorius hatchard had been [[old Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard 's great - uncle]238-old miss hatchard 's great - uncle ; though [she]69-charity would undoubtedly have reversed the phrase , and put forward , as [her]69-charity only claim to distinction , the fact that [she]69-charity was [[his]70-honorius hatchard great - niece]239-his great - niece . For [Honorius Hatchard]70-honorius hatchard , in the early years of the nineteenth century , had enjoyed a modest celebrity . As the marble tablet in the interior of [the library]240-the library informed [its]240-the library infrequent visitors , [he]70-honorius hatchard had possessed marked literary gifts , written a series of papers called “ The Recluse of [Eagle Range]10-eagle range , ”[70-honorius hatchard] enjoyed the acquaintance of [Washington Irving]71-washington irving and [Fitz - Greene Halleck]72-fitz - greene halleck , and been cut off in [his]70-honorius hatchard flower by a fever contracted in [Italy]12-italy . Such had been the sole link between [North Dormer]1-north dormer and literature , a link piously commemorated by the erection of the monument where [Charity Royall]69-charity , every Tuesday and Thursday afternoon , sat at [her]69-charity desk under a freckled steel engraving of [the deceased author]241-the deceased author , and wondered if [he]70-honorius hatchard felt any deader in [his]70-honorius hatchard grave than [she]69-charity did in [[his]70-honorius hatchard library]242-his library . Entering [[her]69-charity prison - house]243-her prison - house with a listless step [she]69-charity took off [her]69-charity hat , hung it on a plaster bust of [Minerva]73-minerva , opened the shutters , leaned out to see if there were any eggs in the swallow 's nest above one of the windows , and finally , seating [herself]69-charity behind the desk , drew out a roll of cotton lace and a steel crochet hook . [She]69-charity was not [an expert workwoman]244-an expert workwoman , and it had taken [her]69-charity many weeks to make the half - yard of narrow lace which [she]69-charity kept wound about the buckram back of a disintegrated copy of “ The Lamplighter . ”[69-charity] But there was no other way of getting any lace to trim [her]69-charity summer blouse , and since [Ally Hawes]74-ally , [the poorest girl in [the village]148-the village]245-the poorest girl in the village , had shown [herself]74-ally in [church]247-church with enviable transparencies about the shoulders , [Charity]69-charity 's hook had travelled faster . [She]69-charity unrolled the lace , dug the hook into a loop , and bent to the task with furrowed brows . Suddenly the door opened , and before [she]69-charity had raised [her]69-charity eyes [she]69-charity knew that [the young man [she]69-charity had seen going in at the Hatchard gate]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate had entered [the library]240-the library . Without taking any notice of [her]69-charity [he]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate began to move slowly about [the long vault - like room]250-the long vault - like room , [his]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate hands behind [his]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate back , [his]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate short - sighted eyes peering up and down the rows of rusty bindings . At length [he]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate reached the desk and stood before [her]69-charity . “ Have [you]69-charity a card - catalogue ? ”[248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate] [he]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate asked in a pleasant abrupt voice ; and the oddness of the question caused [her]69-charity to drop [her]69-charity work . “ A WHAT ? ”[248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate] “ Why , [you]69-charity know---- ”[248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate] [He]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate broke off , and [she]69-charity became conscious that [he]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate was looking at [her]69-charity for the first time , having apparently , on [his]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate entrance , included [her]69-charity in [his]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate general short - sighted survey as part of the furniture of [the library]240-the library . [He]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate smiled also . “ No , [I]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate do n't suppose [you]69-charity do know , ”[248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate] [he]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate corrected [himself]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate . “ In fact , it would be almost a pity---- ”[248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate] [She]69-charity thought [she]69-charity detected a slight condescension in [his]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate tone , and asked sharply : “ Why ? ”[69-charity] “ Because it 's so much pleasanter , in [a small library like this]1877-a small library like this , to poke about by one 's self -- with the help of [the librarian]1878-the librarian . ”[248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate] [He]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate added the last phrase so respectfully that [she]69-charity was mollified , and rejoined with a sigh : “ [I]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate 'm afraid [I]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate ca n't help [you]69-charity much . ”[248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate] “ Why ? ”[248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate] [he]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate questioned in [his]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate turn ; and [she]69-charity replied that there were n't many books anyhow , and that [she]69-charity 'd hardly read any of them . “ The worms are getting at them , ”[69-charity] [she]69-charity added gloomily . “ Are [they]1879-they ? That 's a pity , for [I]69-charity see there are some good ones . ”[69-charity] [He]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate seemed to have lost interest in [their]252-their conversation , and strolled away again , apparently forgetting [her]69-charity . [His]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate indifference nettled [her]69-charity , and [she]69-charity picked up [her]69-charity work , resolved not to offer [him]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate the least assistance . Apparently [he]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate did not need it , for [he]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate spent a long time with [his]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate back to [her]69-charity , lifting down , one after another , the tall cob - webby volumes from a distant shelf . “ Oh , [I]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate say ! ”[248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate] [he]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate exclaimed ; and looking up [she]69-charity saw that [he]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate had drawn out [his]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate handkerchief and was carefully wiping the edges of the book in [his]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate hand . The action struck [her]69-charity as an unwarranted criticism on [her]69-charity care of the books , and [she]69-charity said irritably : “ It 's not [my]69-charity fault if they 're dirty . ”[69-charity] [He]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate turned around and looked at [her]69-charity with reviving interest . “ Ah -- then [you]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate 're not [the librarian]1878-the librarian ? ”[248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate] “ Of course [I]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate am ; but [I]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate ca n't dust all these books . Besides , [nobody]1881-nobody ever looks at them , now [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard 's too lame to come round . ”[248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate] “ No , [I]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate suppose not . ”[248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate] [He]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate laid down the book [he]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate had been wiping , and stood considering [her]69-charity in silence . [She]69-charity wondered if [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard had sent [him]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate round to pry into the way [the library]240-the library was looked after , and the suspicion increased [her]69-charity resentment . “ [I]69-charity saw [you]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate going into [[her]66-miss hatchard house]1882-her house just now , did n't [I]69-charity ? ”[69-charity] [she]69-charity asked , with the New [England]13-england avoidance of the proper name . [She]69-charity was determined to find out why [he]248-the young man she had seen going in at the hatchard gate was poking about among [her]69-charity books . “ [[Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard 's house]1883-miss hatchard 's house ? Yes -- [she]66-miss hatchard 's [[my]173-the young man cousin]1884-my cousin and [I]173-the young man 'm staying [there]185-there , ”[173-the young man] [the young man]173-the young man answered ; adding , as if to disarm a visible distrust : “ [My]173-the young man name is [Harney]75-harney -- [Lucius Harney]75-harney . [She]66-miss hatchard may have spoken of [me]173-the young man . ”[173-the young man] “ No , [she]66-miss hatchard has n't , ”[69-charity] said [Charity]69-charity , wishing [she]69-charity could have said : “ Yes , [she]66-miss hatchard has . ”[69-charity] “ Oh , well---- ”[66-miss hatchard] said [[Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard 's cousin]255-miss hatchard 's cousin with a laugh ; and after another pause , during which it occurred to [Charity]69-charity that [her]69-charity answer had not been encouraging , [he]173-the young man remarked : “ [You]69-charity do n't seem strong on architecture . ”[173-the young man] [Her]69-charity bewilderment was complete : the more [she]69-charity wished to appear to understand [him]173-the young man the more unintelligible [his]173-the young man remarks became . [He]173-the young man reminded [her]69-charity of [the gentleman who had “ explained ”[173-the young man] the pictures at [Nettleton]5-nettleton]256-the gentleman who had “ explained ” the pictures at nettleton , and the weight of [her]69-charity ignorance settled down on [her]69-charity again like a pall . “ [I]256-the gentleman who had “ explained ” the pictures at nettleton mean , [I]256-the gentleman who had “ explained ” the pictures at nettleton ca n't see that [you]173-the young man have any books on [the old houses]1886-the old houses about here . [I]256-the gentleman who had “ explained ” the pictures at nettleton suppose , for that matter , [this part of [the country]1888-the country]1887-this part of the country has n't been much explored . [They]1889-they all go on doing [Plymouth]14-plymouth and [Salem]15-salem . So stupid . [[[My]256-the gentleman who had “ explained ” the pictures at nettleton cousin]1884-my cousin 's house]1891-my cousin 's house , now , is remarkable . [This place]1892-this place must have had a past -- [it]1892-this place must have been more of [a place]1893-a place once . ”[256-the gentleman who had “ explained ” the pictures at nettleton] [He]256-the gentleman who had “ explained ” the pictures at nettleton stopped short , with the blush of [a shy man who overhears [himself]256-the gentleman who had “ explained ” the pictures at nettleton]257-a shy man who overhears himself , and fears [he]256-the gentleman who had “ explained ” the pictures at nettleton has been voluble . “ [I]258-she 'm [an architect]1894-an architect , [you]258-she see , and [I]258-she 'm hunting up [old houses]1895-old houses in these parts . ”[258-she] [She]258-she stared . “ [Old houses]1895-old houses ? Everything 's old in [North Dormer]1-north dormer , is n't it ? [The folks]1897-the folks are , anyhow . ”[258-she] [He]256-the gentleman who had “ explained ” the pictures at nettleton laughed , and wandered away again . “ Have n't [you]258-she any kind of a history of [the place]154-the place ? [I]256-the gentleman who had “ explained ” the pictures at nettleton think there was one written about 1840 : a book or pamphlet about [its]154-the place first settlement , ”[256-the gentleman who had “ explained ” the pictures at nettleton] [he]256-the gentleman who had “ explained ” the pictures at nettleton presently said from the farther end of [the room]259-the room . [She]258-she pressed [her]258-she crochet hook against [her]258-she lip and pondered . There was such a work , [she]258-she knew : “ [North Dormer]1-north dormer and [the Early Townships of [Eagle County]16-eagle county]1899-the early townships of eagle county . ”[258-she] [She]258-she had a special grudge against it because it was a limp weakly book that was always either falling off the shelf or slipping back and disappearing if one squeezed it in between sustaining volumes . [She]258-she remembered , the last time [she]258-she had picked it up , wondering how [anyone]260-anyone could have taken the trouble to write a book about [North Dormer]1-north dormer and [[its]1-north dormer neighbours]261-its neighbours : [Dormer]17-dormer , [Hamblin]18-hamblin , [Creston]19-creston and [Creston River]20-creston river . [She]258-she knew them all , mere lost clusters of houses in [the folds of [the desolate ridges]263-the desolate ridges]262-the folds of the desolate ridges : [Dormer]17-dormer , where [North Dormer]1-north dormer went for [its]1-north dormer apples ; [Creston River]20-creston river , where [there used to be a paper - mill]264-there used to be a paper - mill , and [its]20-creston river grey walls stood decaying by [the stream]265-the stream ; and [Hamblin]18-hamblin , where the first snow always fell . Such were [their]266-their titles to fame . [She]258-she got up and began to move about vaguely before the shelves . But [she]258-she had no idea where [she]258-she had last put the book , and something told [her]258-she that it was going to play [her]258-she its usual trick and remain invisible . It was not one of [her]258-she lucky days . “ [I]258-she guess it 's somewhere , ”[258-she] [she]258-she said , to prove [her]258-she zeal ; but [she]258-she spoke without conviction , and felt that [her]258-she words conveyed none . “ Oh , well---- ”[267-he] [he]267-he said again . [She]258-she knew [he]267-he was going , and wished more than ever to find the book . “ It will be for next time , ”[267-he] [he]267-he added ; and picking up the volume [he]267-he had laid on the desk [he]267-he handed it to [her]258-she . “ By the way , a little air and sun would do this good ; it 's rather valuable . ”[267-he] [He]267-he gave [her]258-she a nod and smile , and passed out . II The hours of [the Hatchard Memorial librarian]268-the hatchard memorial librarian were from three to five ; and [Charity Royall]69-charity 's sense of duty usually kept [her]69-charity at [her]69-charity desk until nearly half - past four . But [she]69-charity had never perceived that any practical advantage thereby accrued either to [North Dormer]1-north dormer or to [herself]69-charity ; and [she]69-charity had no scruple in decreeing , when it suited [her]69-charity , that [the library]240-the library should close an hour earlier . A few minutes after [Mr. Harney]76-harney 's departure [she]69-charity formed this decision , put away [her]69-charity lace , fastened the shutters , and turned the key in the door of [the temple of knowledge]270-the temple of knowledge . [The street upon which [she]69-charity emerged]271-the street upon which she emerged was still empty : and after glancing up and down [it]271-the street upon which she emerged [she]69-charity began to walk toward [[her]69-charity house]1882-her house . But instead of entering [she]69-charity passed on , turned into [a field - path]273-a field - path and mounted to [a pasture on [the hillside]275-the hillside]274-a pasture on the hillside . [She]69-charity let down the bars of the gate , followed a trail along the crumbling wall of [the pasture]276-the pasture , and walked on till [she]69-charity reached [a knoll]277-a knoll where a clump of larches shook out their fresh tassels to the wind . There [she]69-charity lay down on [the slope]278-the slope , tossed off [her]69-charity hat and hid [her]69-charity face in the grass . [She]69-charity was blind and insensible to many things , and dimly knew it ; but to all that was light and air , perfume and colour , every drop of blood in [her]69-charity responded . [She]69-charity loved the roughness of the dry mountain grass under [her]69-charity palms , the smell of the thyme into which [she]69-charity crushed [her]69-charity face , the fingering of the wind in [her]69-charity hair and through [her]69-charity cotton blouse , and the creak of the larches as they swayed to it . [She]69-charity often climbed up [the hill]279-the hill and lay there alone for the mere pleasure of feeling the wind and of rubbing [her]69-charity cheeks in the grass . Generally at such times [she]69-charity did not think of anything , but lay immersed in an inarticulate well - being . Today the sense of well - being was intensified by [her]69-charity joy at escaping from [the library]240-the library . [She]69-charity liked well enough to have [a friend]281-a friend drop in and talk to [her]69-charity when [she]69-charity was on duty , but [she]69-charity hated to be bothered about books . How could [she]69-charity remember where they were , when they were so seldom asked for ? [Orma Fry]77-orma fry occasionally took out a novel , and [[her]77-orma fry brother]282-her brother [Ben]78-ben fry was fond of what [he]78-ben fry called “ jography , ”[78-ben fry] and of books relating to trade and bookkeeping ; but [no one else]283-no one else asked for anything except , at intervals , “ [Uncle Tom]79-uncle tom 's Cabin , ”[78-ben fry] or “ Opening of [a Chestnut Burr]1900-a chestnut burr , ”[78-ben fry] or [Longfellow]80-longfellow . [She]69-charity had these under [her]69-charity hand , and could have found them in the dark ; but unexpected demands came so rarely that they exasperated [her]69-charity like an injustice .... [She]69-charity had liked [the young man]173-the young man 's looks , and [his]173-the young man short - sighted eyes , and [his]173-the young man odd way of speaking , that was abrupt yet soft , just as [his]173-the young man hands were sun - burnt and sinewy , yet with smooth nails like [a woman]285-a woman 's . [His]173-the young man hair was sunburnt - looking too , or rather the colour of bracken after frost ; [his]173-the young man eyes grey , with the appealing look of the shortsighted , [his]173-the young man smile shy yet confident , as if [he]173-the young man knew lots of things [she]69-charity had never dreamed of , and yet would n't for [the world]184-the world have had [her]69-charity feel [his]173-the young man superiority . But [she]69-charity did feel it , and liked the feeling ; for it was new to [her]69-charity . Poor and ignorant as [she]69-charity was , and knew [herself]69-charity to be -- humblest of [the humble even in [North Dormer]1-north dormer]287-the humble even in north dormer , where to come from [the Mountain]8-the mountain was the worst disgrace -- yet in [[her]69-charity narrow world [she]69-charity had always ruled]288-her narrow world she had always ruled . It was partly , of course , owing to the fact that [lawyer Royall]69-charity was “ [the biggest man in [North Dormer]1-north dormer]1901-the biggest man in north dormer ”[69-charity] ; so much too big for it , in fact , that [outsiders]289-outsiders , who did n't know , always wondered how it held [him]173-the young man . In spite of everything -- and in spite even of [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard -- [lawyer Royall]69-charity ruled in [North Dormer]1-north dormer ; and [Charity]69-charity ruled in [[lawyer Royall]69-charity 's house]145-lawyer royall 's house . [She]69-charity had never put it to [herself]69-charity in those terms ; but [she]69-charity knew [her]69-charity power , knew what it was made of , and hated it . Confusedly , [the young man in [the library]240-the library]291-the young man in the library had made [her]69-charity feel for the first time what might be the sweetness of dependence . [She]69-charity sat up , brushed the bits of grass from [her]69-charity hair , and looked down on [the house where [she]69-charity held sway]293-the house where she held sway . [It]293-the house where she held sway stood just below [her]69-charity , cheerless and untended , [its]293-the house where she held sway faded red front divided from [the road]160-the road by [a “ yard ”]1902-a “ yard ”[293-the house where she held sway] with a path bordered by gooseberry bushes , a stone well overgrown with [traveller]295-traveller 's joy , and a sickly Crimson Rambler tied to a fan - shaped support , which [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall had once brought up from [Hepburn]4-hepburn to please [her]69-charity . Behind [the house]171-the house a bit of uneven ground with clothes - lines strung across [it]297-it stretched up to a dry wall , and beyond the wall a patch of corn and a few rows of potatoes strayed vaguely into [the adjoining wilderness of rock and fern]298-the adjoining wilderness of rock and fern . [Charity]69-charity could not recall [her]69-charity first sight of [the house]171-the house . [She]69-charity had been told that [she]69-charity was ill of a fever when [she]69-charity was brought down from [the Mountain]231-the mountain ; and [she]69-charity could only remember waking one day in a cot at the foot of [Mrs. Royall]81-mrs. royall 's bed , and opening [her]69-charity eyes on the cold neatness of [the room that was afterward to be [hers]69-charity]301-the room that was afterward to be hers . [Mrs. Royall]81-mrs. royall died seven or eight years later ; and by that time [Charity]69-charity had taken the measure of most things about [her]81-mrs. royall . [She]69-charity knew that [Mrs. Royall]81-mrs. royall was sad and timid and weak ; [she]69-charity knew that [lawyer Royall]64-mr. royall was harsh and violent , and still weaker . [She]69-charity knew that [she]69-charity had been christened [Charity]69-charity ( in [the white church at [the other end of [the village]148-the village]158-the other end of the village]302-the white church at the other end of the village ) to commemorate [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall 's disinterestedness in “ bringing [her]69-charity down , ”[69-charity] and to keep alive in [her]69-charity a becoming sense of [her]69-charity dependence ; [she]69-charity knew that [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall was [[her]69-charity guardian]305-her guardian , but that [he]64-mr. royall had not legally adopted [her]69-charity , though [everybody]306-everybody spoke of [her]69-charity as [Charity Royall]69-charity ; and [she]69-charity knew why [he]64-mr. royall had come back to live at [North Dormer]1-north dormer , instead of practising at [Nettleton]5-nettleton , where [he]64-mr. royall had begun [his]64-mr. royall legal career . After [Mrs. Royall]81-mrs. royall 's death there was some talk of sending [her]69-charity to [a boarding - school]307-a boarding - school . [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard suggested it , and had a long conference with [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall , who , in pursuance of [her]66-miss hatchard plan , departed one day for [Starkfield]82-starkfield to visit [the institution [she]66-miss hatchard recommended]308-the institution she recommended . [He]64-mr. royall came back the next night with a black face ; worse , [Charity]69-charity observed , than [she]69-charity had ever seen [him]64-mr. royall ; and by that time [she]69-charity had had some experience . When [she]69-charity asked [him]64-mr. royall how soon [she]69-charity was to start [he]64-mr. royall answered shortly , “ [You]69-charity ai n't going , ”[64-mr. royall] and shut [himself]64-mr. royall up in [the room [he]64-mr. royall called [[his]64-mr. royall office]310-his office]309-the room he called his office ; and the next day [the lady who kept [the school]312-the school at [Starkfield]82-starkfield]311-the lady who kept the school at starkfield wrote that “ under the circumstances ”[311-the lady who kept the school at starkfield] [she]311-the lady who kept the school at starkfield was afraid [she]311-the lady who kept the school at starkfield could not make room just then for [another pupil]313-another pupil . [Charity]69-charity was disappointed ; but [she]69-charity understood . It was n't the temptations of [Starkfield]82-starkfield that had been [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall 's undoing ; it was the thought of losing [her]69-charity . [He]64-mr. royall was [a dreadfully “ lonesome ”[64-mr. royall] man]314-a dreadfully “ lonesome ” man ; [she]69-charity had made that out because [she]69-charity was so “ lonesome ”[69-charity] [herself]69-charity . [He]64-mr. royall and [she]69-charity , face to face in [that sad house]315-that sad house , had sounded the depths of isolation ; and though [she]69-charity felt no particular affection for [him]64-mr. royall , and not the slightest gratitude , [she]69-charity pitied [him]64-mr. royall because [she]69-charity was conscious that [he]64-mr. royall was superior to [the people about [him]64-mr. royall]316-the people about him , and that [she]69-charity was the only being between [him]64-mr. royall and solitude . Therefore , when [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard sent for [her]69-charity a day or two later , to talk of [a school at [Nettleton]5-nettleton]317-a school at nettleton , and to say that this time [a friend of hers]318-a friend of hers would “ make the necessary arrangements , ”[69-charity] [Charity]69-charity cut [her]69-charity short with the announcement that [she]69-charity had decided not to leave [North Dormer]1-north dormer . [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard reasoned with [her]69-charity kindly , but to no purpose ; [she]66-miss hatchard simply repeated : “ [I]66-miss hatchard guess [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall 's too lonesome . ”[66-miss hatchard] [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard blinked perplexedly behind [her]66-miss hatchard eye - glasses . [Her]66-miss hatchard long frail face was full of puzzled wrinkles , and [she]66-miss hatchard leant forward , resting [her]66-miss hatchard hands on the arms of [her]66-miss hatchard mahogany armchair , with the evident desire to say something that ought to be said . “ The feeling does [you]69-charity credit , [[my]66-miss hatchard dear]1903-my dear . ”[66-miss hatchard] [She]66-miss hatchard looked about the pale walls of [[her]66-miss hatchard sitting - room]319-her sitting - room , seeking counsel of ancestral daguerreotypes and didactic samplers ; but they seemed to make utterance more difficult . “ The fact is , it 's not only -- not only because of the advantages . There are other reasons . [You]69-charity 're too young to understand---- ”[66-miss hatchard] “ Oh , no , [I]69-charity ai n't , ”[69-charity] said [Charity]69-charity harshly ; and [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard blushed to the roots of [her]66-miss hatchard blonde cap . But [she]66-miss hatchard must have felt a vague relief at having [her]66-miss hatchard explanation cut short , for [she]66-miss hatchard concluded , again invoking the daguerreotypes : “ Of course [I]66-miss hatchard shall always do what [I]66-miss hatchard can for [you]69-charity ; and in case ... in case ... [you]69-charity know [you]69-charity can always come to [me]66-miss hatchard .... ”[66-miss hatchard] [Lawyer Royall]83-lawyer royall was waiting for [Charity]69-charity in [the porch]320-the porch when [she]69-charity returned from this visit . [He]83-lawyer royall had shaved , and brushed [his]83-lawyer royall black coat , and looked [a magnificent monument of [a man]322-a man]321-a magnificent monument of a man ; at such moments [she]69-charity really admired [him]83-lawyer royall . “ Well , ”[83-lawyer royall] [he]83-lawyer royall said , “ is it settled ? ”[83-lawyer royall] “ Yes , it 's settled . [I]83-lawyer royall ai n't going . ”[83-lawyer royall] “ Not to [the Nettleton school]1904-the nettleton school ? ”[83-lawyer royall] “ Not anywhere . ”[83-lawyer royall] [He]83-lawyer royall cleared [his]83-lawyer royall throat and asked sternly : “ Why ? ”[83-lawyer royall] “ [I]69-charity 'd rather not , ”[69-charity] [she]69-charity said , swinging past [him]83-lawyer royall on [her]69-charity way to [[her]69-charity room]323-her room . It was the following week that [he]83-lawyer royall brought [her]69-charity up the Crimson Rambler and its fan from [Hepburn]4-hepburn . [He]83-lawyer royall had never given [her]69-charity anything before . The next outstanding incident of [her]69-charity life had happened two years later , when [she]69-charity was seventeen . [Lawyer Royall]83-lawyer royall , who hated to go to [Nettleton]5-nettleton , had been called [there]185-there in connection with a case . [He]83-lawyer royall still exercised [his]83-lawyer royall profession , though litigation languished in [North Dormer]1-north dormer and [its outlying hamlets]325-its outlying hamlets ; and for once [he]83-lawyer royall had had an opportunity that [he]83-lawyer royall could not afford to refuse . [He]83-lawyer royall spent three days in [Nettleton]5-nettleton , won [his]83-lawyer royall case , and came back in high good - humour . It was a rare mood with [him]83-lawyer royall , and manifested itself on this occasion by [his]83-lawyer royall talking impressively at the supper - table of the “ rousing welcome ”[83-lawyer royall] [[his]83-lawyer royall old friends]326-his old friends had given [him]83-lawyer royall . [He]83-lawyer royall wound up confidentially : “ [I]83-lawyer royall was [a damn fool]1905-a damn fool ever to leave [Nettleton]5-nettleton . It was [Mrs. Royall]81-mrs. royall that made [me]83-lawyer royall do it . ”[83-lawyer royall] [Charity]69-charity immediately perceived that something bitter had happened to [him]83-lawyer royall , and that [he]83-lawyer royall was trying to talk down the recollection . [She]69-charity went up to bed early , leaving [him]83-lawyer royall seated in moody thought , [his]83-lawyer royall elbows propped on the worn oilcloth of the supper table . On the way up [she]69-charity had extracted from [his]83-lawyer royall overcoat pocket the key of the cupboard where the bottle of whiskey was kept . [She]69-charity was awakened by a rattling at [her]69-charity door and jumped out of bed . [She]69-charity heard [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall 's voice , low and peremptory , and opened the door , fearing an accident . No other thought had occurred to [her]69-charity ; but when [she]69-charity saw [him]83-lawyer royall in the doorway , a ray from the autumn moon falling on [his]83-lawyer royall discomposed face , [she]69-charity understood . For a moment [they]327-they looked at [each other]328-each other in silence ; then , as [he]83-lawyer royall put [his]83-lawyer royall foot across the threshold , [she]69-charity stretched out [her]69-charity arm and stopped [him]83-lawyer royall . “ [You]83-lawyer royall go right back from here , ”[69-charity] [she]69-charity said , in a shrill voice that startled [her]69-charity ; “ [you]83-lawyer royall ai n't going to have that key tonight . ”[69-charity] “ [Charity]69-charity , let [me]83-lawyer royall in . [I]83-lawyer royall do n't want the key . [I]83-lawyer royall 'm [a lonesome man]1906-a lonesome man , ”[83-lawyer royall] [he]83-lawyer royall began , in the deep voice that sometimes moved [her]69-charity . [Her]69-charity heart gave a startled plunge , but [she]69-charity continued to hold [him]83-lawyer royall back contemptuously . “ Well , [I]69-charity guess [you]83-lawyer royall made a mistake , then . This ai n't [[[your]83-lawyer royall wife]1907-your wife 's room]1908-your wife 's room any longer . ”[69-charity] [She]69-charity was not frightened , [she]69-charity simply felt a deep disgust ; and perhaps [he]83-lawyer royall divined it or read it in [her]69-charity face , for after staring at [her]69-charity a moment [he]83-lawyer royall drew back and turned slowly away from the door . With [her]69-charity ear to [her]69-charity keyhole [she]69-charity heard [him]83-lawyer royall feel [his]83-lawyer royall way down [the dark stairs]329-the dark stairs , and toward [the kitchen]330-the kitchen ; and [she]69-charity listened for the crash of the cupboard panel , but instead [she]69-charity heard [him]83-lawyer royall , after an interval , unlock the door of [the house]171-the house , and [his]83-lawyer royall heavy steps came to [her]69-charity through the silence as [he]83-lawyer royall walked down [the path]332-the path . [She]69-charity crept to the window and saw [his]83-lawyer royall bent figure striding up [the road]160-the road in the moonlight . Then a belated sense of fear came to [her]69-charity with the consciousness of victory , and [she]69-charity slipped into bed , cold to the bone . A day or two later [poor Eudora Skeff]84-eudora , who for twenty years had been [the custodian of [the Hatchard library]335-the hatchard library]334-the custodian of the hatchard library , died suddenly of pneumonia ; and the day after the funeral [Charity]69-charity went to see [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard , and asked to be appointed [librarian]336-librarian . The request seemed to surprise [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard : [she]69-charity evidently questioned [the new candidate]337-the new candidate 's qualifications . “ Why , [I]69-charity do n't know , [[my]69-charity dear]1903-my dear . Are n't [you]1903-my dear rather too young ? ”[69-charity] [she]69-charity hesitated . “ [I]69-charity want to earn some money , ”[69-charity] [Charity]69-charity merely answered . “ Does n't [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall give [you]1903-my dear all [you]1903-my dear require ? [No one]1910-no one is rich in [North Dormer]1-north dormer . ”[69-charity] “ [I]66-miss hatchard want to earn money enough to get away . ”[66-miss hatchard] “ To get away ? ”[66-miss hatchard] [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard 's puzzled wrinkles deepened , and there was a distressful pause . “ [You]1903-my dear want to leave [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall ? ”[66-miss hatchard] “ Yes : or [I]69-charity want [another woman in [the house]171-the house]1911-another woman in the house with [me]69-charity , ”[69-charity] said [Charity]69-charity resolutely . [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard clasped [her]66-miss hatchard nervous hands about the arms of [her]66-miss hatchard chair . [Her]66-miss hatchard eyes invoked the faded countenances on the wall , and after a faint cough of indecision [she]66-miss hatchard brought out : “ The ... [the housework]1913-the housework 's too hard for [you]66-miss hatchard , [I]66-miss hatchard suppose ? ”[66-miss hatchard] [Charity]69-charity 's heart grew cold . [She]69-charity understood that [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard had no help to give [her]69-charity and that [she]69-charity would have to fight [her]69-charity way out of [her]69-charity difficulty alone . A deeper sense of isolation overcame [her]69-charity ; [she]69-charity felt incalculably old . “ [She]84-eudora 's got to be talked to like [a baby]1914-a baby , ”[69-charity] [she]69-charity thought , with a feeling of compassion for [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard 's long immaturity . “ Yes , that 's it , ”[69-charity] [she]69-charity said aloud . “ [The housework]1913-the housework 's too hard for [me]69-charity : [I]69-charity 've been coughing a good deal this fall . ”[69-charity] [She]69-charity noted the immediate effect of this suggestion . [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard paled at the memory of poor [Eudora]84-eudora 's taking - off , and promised to do what [she]66-miss hatchard could . [They]343-they had met at meals during the five days that had elapsed since [he]64-mr. royall had come to [her]69-charity door , and [she]69-charity had walked at [his]64-mr. royall side at [Eudora]84-eudora 's funeral ; but [they]343-they had not spoken a word to [each other]328-each other . [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall had grown exceedingly pale . When [she]346-i ended [he]64-mr. royall stood up ponderously , leaning against the desk ; and for a second or two [they]347-they looked at [each other]328-each other . “ See here , ”[64-mr. royall] [he]64-mr. royall said at length as though utterance were difficult , “ there 's something [I]64-mr. royall 've been wanting to say to [you]180-the girl ; [I]64-mr. royall 'd ought to have said it before . [I]64-mr. royall 'll do whatever [you]180-the girl say . ”[64-mr. royall] [His]64-mr. royall eyes fell under the merciless stare [she]180-the girl continued to fix on [him]64-mr. royall , and [he]64-mr. royall shifted [his]64-mr. royall weight uneasily from one foot to the other . Then [he]64-mr. royall went out . A few days later [North Dormer]1-north dormer learned with surprise that [Charity]69-charity had been appointed [librarian of [the Hatchard Memorial]353-the hatchard memorial]352-librarian of the hatchard memorial at a salary of eight dollars a month , and that [old Verena Marsh]87-verena , from [the Creston Almshouse]354-the creston almshouse , was coming to live at [[lawyer Royall]64-mr. royall 's]355-lawyer royall 's and do the cooking . III It was not in [the room known at [the red house]357-the red house]356-the room known at the red house as [[Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall 's “ office ”]1933-mr. royall 's “ office ”[64-mr. royall] that [he]64-mr. royall received [[his]64-mr. royall infrequent clients]358-his infrequent clients . Professional dignity and masculine independence made it necessary that [he]64-mr. royall should have [a real office]359-a real office , under a different roof ; and [his]64-mr. royall standing as [the only lawyer of [North Dormer]1-north dormer]360-the only lawyer of north dormer required that the roof should be the same as that which sheltered [the Town Hall]361-the town hall and [the post - office]362-the post - office . It was [his]64-mr. royall habit to walk to [this office]363-this office twice a day , morning and afternoon . [It]363-this office was on [the ground floor of [the building]365-the building]364-the ground floor of the building , with a separate entrance , and a weathered name - plate on the door . Before going in [he]64-mr. royall stepped in to [the post - office]362-the post - office for [his]64-mr. royall mail -- usually an empty ceremony -- said a word or two to [the town - clerk]367-the town - clerk , who sat across [the passage]368-the passage in idle state , and then went over to [the store]369-the store on the opposite corner , where [Carrick Fry]88-carrick fry , [the storekeeper]370-the storekeeper , always kept a chair for [him]64-mr. royall , and where [he]64-mr. royall was sure to find [one or two selectmen]371-one or two selectmen leaning on the long counter , in an atmosphere of rope , leather , tar and coffee - beans . [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall , though monosyllabic at [home]342-home , was not averse , in certain moods , to imparting [his]64-mr. royall views to [[his]64-mr. royall fellow - townsmen]373-his fellow - townsmen ; perhaps , also , [he]64-mr. royall was unwilling that [[his]64-mr. royall rare clients]374-his rare clients should surprise [him]64-mr. royall sitting , clerkless and unoccupied , in [[his]64-mr. royall dusty office]375-his dusty office . At any rate , [his]64-mr. royall hours there were not much longer or more regular than [Charity]69-charity 's at [the library]240-the library ; the rest of the time [he]64-mr. royall spent either at [the store]369-the store or in driving about [the country]1888-the country on business connected with [the insurance companies that [he]64-mr. royall represented]379-the insurance companies that he represented , or in sitting at [home]342-home reading [Bancroft]89-bancroft 's History of [the United States]381-the united states and the speeches of [Daniel Webster]85-daniel webster . Since the day when [Charity]69-charity had told [him]64-mr. royall that [she]69-charity wished to succeed to [Eudora Skeff]84-eudora 's post [their]382-their relations had undefinably but definitely changed . [Lawyer Royall]83-lawyer royall had kept [his]83-lawyer royall word . [He]83-lawyer royall had obtained the place for [her]69-charity at the cost of considerable maneuvering , as [she]69-charity guessed from the number of [rival candidates]383-rival candidates , and from the acerbity with which two of [them]383-rival candidates , [Orma Fry]77-orma fry and [the eldest Targatt girl]384-the eldest targatt girl , treated [her]69-charity for nearly a year afterward . And [he]83-lawyer royall had engaged [Verena Marsh]87-verena to come up from [Creston]19-creston and do the cooking . [Verena]87-verena was [a poor old widow , doddering and shiftless]385-a poor old widow , doddering and shiftless : [Charity]69-charity suspected that [she]87-verena came for [her]87-verena keep . [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall was too close [a man]322-a man to give a dollar a day to [a smart girl]387-a smart girl when [he]83-lawyer royall could get [a deaf pauper]388-a deaf pauper for nothing . But at any rate , [Verena]87-verena was there , in [the attic just over [Charity]69-charity]389-the attic just over charity , and the fact that [she]87-verena was deaf did not greatly trouble [the young girl]390-the young girl . [Charity]69-charity knew that what had happened on that hateful night would not happen again . [She]69-charity understood that , profoundly as [she]69-charity had despised [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall ever since , [he]64-mr. royall despised [himself]64-mr. royall still more profoundly . If [she]69-charity had asked for [a woman in [the house]171-the house]391-a woman in the house it was far less for [her]69-charity own defense than for [his]64-mr. royall humiliation . [She]69-charity needed [no one]1910-no one to defend [her]69-charity : [his]64-mr. royall humbled pride was [her]69-charity surest protection . [He]64-mr. royall had never spoken a word of excuse or extenuation ; the incident was as if it had never been . Yet its consequences were latent in every word that [he]64-mr. royall and [she]69-charity exchanged , in every glance [they]394-they instinctively turned from each other . Nothing now would ever shake [her]69-charity rule in [the red house]357-the red house . On the night of [her]69-charity meeting with [[Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard 's cousin]255-miss hatchard 's cousin [Charity]69-charity lay in bed , [her]69-charity bare arms clasped under [her]69-charity rough head , and continued to think of [him]64-mr. royall . [She]69-charity supposed that [he]64-mr. royall meant to spend some time in [North Dormer]1-north dormer . [He]64-mr. royall had said [he]64-mr. royall was looking up [the old houses in [the neighbourhood]398-the neighbourhood]397-the old houses in the neighbourhood ; and though [she]69-charity was not very clear as to [his]64-mr. royall purpose , or as to why [anyone]260-anyone should look for [old houses]1895-old houses , when [they]260-anyone lay in wait for one on [every roadside]401-every roadside , [she]69-charity understood that [he]64-mr. royall needed the help of books , and resolved to hunt up the next day the volume [she]69-charity had failed to find , and any others that seemed related to the subject . Never had [her]69-charity ignorance of life and literature so weighed on [her]69-charity as in reliving the short scene of [her]69-charity discomfiture . “ It 's no use trying to be anything in [this place]1892-this place , ”[69-charity] [she]69-charity muttered to [her]69-charity pillow ; and [she]69-charity shrivelled at the vision of [vague metropolises , shining super - [Nettletons]21-nettletons , where [girls in better clothes]403-girls in better clothes than [Belle Balch]90-belle balch 's]402-vague metropolises , shining super - nettletons , where girls in better clothes than belle balch 's talked fluently of architecture to [young men]404-young men with hands like [Lucius Harney]75-harney 's . Then [she]69-charity remembered [his]64-mr. royall sudden pause when [he]64-mr. royall had come close to the desk and had [his]64-mr. royall first look at [her]69-charity . The sight had made [him]64-mr. royall forget what [he]64-mr. royall was going to say ; [she]69-charity recalled the change in [his]64-mr. royall face , and jumping up [she]69-charity ran over the bare boards to [[her]69-charity washstand]405-her washstand , found the matches , lit a candle , and lifted it to the square of looking - glass on the white - washed wall . [Her]69-charity small face , usually so darkly pale , glowed like a rose in the faint orb of light , and under [her]69-charity rumpled hair [her]69-charity eyes seemed deeper and larger than by day . Perhaps after all it was a mistake to wish they were blue . A clumsy band and button fastened [her]69-charity unbleached night - gown about the throat . [She]69-charity undid it , freed [her]69-charity thin shoulders , and saw [herself]69-charity [a bride in low - necked satin]406-a bride in low - necked satin , walking down [an aisle]407-an aisle with [Lucius Harney]75-harney . [He]64-mr. royall would kiss [her]69-charity as [they]408-they left [the church]161-the church .... [She]69-charity put down the candle and covered [her]69-charity face with [her]69-charity hands as if to imprison the kiss . At that moment [she]69-charity heard [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall 's step as [he]64-mr. royall came up the stairs to bed , and a fierce revulsion of feeling swept over [her]69-charity . Until then [she]69-charity had merely despised [him]64-mr. royall ; now deep hatred of [him]64-mr. royall filled [her]69-charity heart . [He]64-mr. royall became to [her]69-charity [a horrible old man]410-a horrible old man .... The next day , when [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall came back to dinner , [they]408-they faced [each other]328-each other in silence as usual . [Verena]87-verena 's presence at the table was an excuse for [their]408-they not talking , though [her]87-verena deafness would have permitted the freest interchange of confidences . But when the meal was over , and [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall rose from the table , [he]64-mr. royall looked back at [Charity]69-charity , who had stayed to help [the old woman]412-the old woman clear away the dishes . “ [I]64-mr. royall want to speak to [you]69-charity a minute , ”[64-mr. royall] [he]64-mr. royall said ; and [she]69-charity followed [him]64-mr. royall across [the passage]368-the passage , wondering . [He]64-mr. royall seated [himself]64-mr. royall in [his]64-mr. royall black horse - hair armchair , and [she]69-charity leaned against the window , indifferently . [She]69-charity was impatient to be gone to [the library]240-the library , to hunt for the book on [North Dormer]1-north dormer . “ See here , ”[64-mr. royall] [he]64-mr. royall said , “ why ai n't [you]69-charity at [the library]240-the library the days [you]69-charity 're supposed to be [there]185-there ? ”[64-mr. royall] The question , breaking in on [her]69-charity mood of blissful abstraction , deprived [her]69-charity of speech , and [she]69-charity stared at [him]64-mr. royall for a moment without answering . “ Who says [I]69-charity ai n't ? ”[69-charity] “ There 's been some complaints made , it appears . So [she]66-miss hatchard sent for [me]69-charity , and told [me]69-charity about that , and about the other complaints . [She]66-miss hatchard claims [you]416-you 've neglected things , and that [she]66-miss hatchard 's going to get [a trained librarian]1949-a trained librarian . ”[69-charity] [Charity]69-charity had not moved while [he]416-you spoke . [She]69-charity stood with [her]69-charity head thrown back against the window - frame , [her]69-charity arms hanging against [her]69-charity sides , and [her]69-charity hands so tightly clenched that [she]69-charity felt , without knowing what hurt [her]69-charity , the sharp edge of [her]69-charity nails against [her]69-charity palms . Of all [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall had said [she]69-charity had retained only the phrase : “ [He]64-mr. royall told [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard the books were in bad shape . ”[69-charity] What did [she]69-charity care for the other charges against [her]69-charity ? Malice or truth , [she]69-charity despised [them]417-them as [she]69-charity despised [[her]69-charity detractors]418-her detractors . But that [the stranger to whom [she]69-charity had felt [herself]69-charity so mysteriously drawn]419-the stranger to whom she had felt herself so mysteriously drawn should have betrayed [her]69-charity ! That at the very moment when [she]69-charity had fled up [the hillside]275-the hillside to think of [him]419-the stranger to whom she had felt herself so mysteriously drawn more deliciously [he]419-the stranger to whom she had felt herself so mysteriously drawn should have been hastening [home]342-home to denounce [her]69-charity short - comings ! [She]69-charity remembered how , in the darkness of [[her]69-charity room]323-her room , [she]69-charity had covered [her]69-charity face to press [his]419-the stranger to whom she had felt herself so mysteriously drawn imagined kiss closer ; and [her]69-charity heart raged against [him]419-the stranger to whom she had felt herself so mysteriously drawn for the liberty [he]419-the stranger to whom she had felt herself so mysteriously drawn had not taken . “ Well , [I]69-charity 'll go , ”[69-charity] [she]69-charity said suddenly . “ [I]69-charity 'll go right off . ”[69-charity] “ Go where ? ”[69-charity] [She]69-charity heard the startled note in [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall 's voice . “ Why , out of [[their]1950-they old library]1951-their old library : straight out , and never set foot in [it]1951-their old library again . [They]1950-they need n't think [I]64-mr. royall 'm going to wait round and let [them]1950-they say [they]1950-they 've discharged [me]64-mr. royall ! ”[64-mr. royall] “ [Charity]69-charity -- [Charity Royall]69-charity , [you]69-charity listen---- ”[64-mr. royall] [he]64-mr. royall began , getting heavily out of [his]64-mr. royall chair ; but [she]69-charity waved [him]64-mr. royall aside , and walked out of [the room]259-the room . [Upstairs]424-upstairs [she]69-charity took the library key from the place where [she]69-charity always hid it under [her]69-charity pincushion -- who said [she]69-charity was n't careful?--put on [her]69-charity hat , and swept down again and out into [the street]163-the street . If [Mr. Royall]64-mr. royall heard [her]69-charity go [he]64-mr. royall made no motion to detain [her]69-charity : [his]64-mr. royall sudden rages probably made [him]64-mr. royall understand the uselessness of reasoning with [hers]69-charity . [She]69-charity reached [the brick temple]426-the brick temple , unlocked the door and entered into the glacial twilight . “ [I]69-charity 'm glad [I]69-charity 'll never have to sit in [this old vault]1952-this old vault again when [other folks]1953-other folks are out in the sun ! ”[69-charity] [she]69-charity said aloud as the familiar chill took [her]69-charity . [She]69-charity looked with abhorrence at the long dingy rows of books , the sheep - nosed Minerva on [her]69-charity black pedestal , and [the mild - faced young man in a high stock whose effigy pined above [her]69-charity desk]427-the mild - faced young man in a high stock whose effigy pined above her desk . [She]69-charity meant to take out of the drawer [her]69-charity roll of lace and the library register , and go straight to [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard to announce [her]69-charity resignation . But suddenly a great desolation overcame [her]69-charity , and [she]69-charity sat down and laid [her]69-charity face against the desk . [Her]69-charity heart was ravaged by life 's cruelest discovery : [the first creature who had come toward [her]69-charity out of [the wilderness]429-the wilderness]428-the first creature who had come toward her out of the wilderness had brought [her]69-charity anguish instead of joy . [She]69-charity did not cry ; tears came hard to [her]69-charity , and the storms of [her]69-charity heart spent themselves inwardly . But as [she]69-charity sat there in [her]69-charity dumb woe [she]69-charity felt [her]69-charity life to be too desolate , too ugly and intolerable . “ What have [I]69-charity ever done to it , that it should hurt [me]69-charity so ? ”[69-charity] [she]69-charity groaned , and pressed [her]69-charity fists against [her]69-charity lids , which were beginning to swell with weeping . “ [I]69-charity won't -- [I]69-charity wo n't go there looking like a horror ! ”[69-charity] [she]69-charity muttered , springing up and pushing back [her]69-charity hair as if it stifled [her]69-charity . [She]69-charity opened the drawer , dragged out the register , and turned toward the door . As [she]69-charity did so it opened , and [the young man from [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard 's]430-the young man from miss hatchard 's came in whistling . IV [He]430-the young man from miss hatchard 's stopped and lifted [his]430-the young man from miss hatchard 's hat with a shy smile . “ [I]430-the young man from miss hatchard 's beg [your]69-charity pardon , ”[430-the young man from miss hatchard 's] [he]430-the young man from miss hatchard 's said . “ [I]430-the young man from miss hatchard 's thought there was [no one]1910-no one [here]1923-here . ”[430-the young man from miss hatchard 's] [Charity]69-charity stood before [him]430-the young man from miss hatchard 's , barring [his]430-the young man from miss hatchard 's way . “ [You]430-the young man from miss hatchard 's ca n't come in . [The library]240-the library ai n't open to the public Wednesdays . ”[69-charity] “ [I]173-the young man know it 's not ; but [[my]173-the young man cousin]1884-my cousin gave [me]173-the young man [her]1884-my cousin key . ”[173-the young man] “ [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard 's got no right to give [her]1884-my cousin key to [other folks]1953-other folks , any more'n [I]173-the young man have . [I]173-the young man 'm [the librarian]1878-the librarian and [I]173-the young man know the by - laws . This is [[my]173-the young man library]1960-my library . ”[173-the young man] [The young man]173-the young man looked profoundly surprised . “ Why , [I]173-the young man know it is ; [I]173-the young man 'm so sorry if [you]430-the young man from miss hatchard 's mind [my]173-the young man coming . ”[173-the young man] “ [I]91-young harney suppose [you]430-the young man from miss hatchard 's came to see what more [you]430-the young man from miss hatchard 's could say to set [her]1884-my cousin against [me]91-young harney ? Why should [I]173-the young man say things against [you]430-the young man from miss hatchard 's to [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard -- or to [anyone]260-anyone ? ”[173-the young man] The apparent evasiveness of the reply caused [Charity]69-charity 's indignation to overflow . “ [I]433-i do n't know why [you]430-the young man from miss hatchard 's should . [I]433-i could understand [Orma Fry]77-orma fry 's doing it , because [she]77-orma fry 's always wanted to get [me]433-i out of [here]1923-here ever since the first day . [I]433-i ca n't see why , when [she]77-orma fry 's got [[her]77-orma fry own [home]342-home]1964-her own home , and [[her]77-orma fry father]1966-her father to work for [her]77-orma fry ; nor [Ida Targatt]92-ida targatt , neither , when [she]77-orma fry got a legacy from [[her]77-orma fry step - brother]1967-her step - brother on'y last year . But [you]1973-you do n't live [here]1923-here , and [you]1973-you do n't know anything about [any of [us]1968-we]1975-any of us , so what did [you]1973-you have to meddle for ? Do [you]1973-you suppose [the other girls'd]1976-the other girls'd have kept the books any better'n [I]433-i did ? Why , [Orma Fry]77-orma fry do n't hardly know a book from a flat - iron ! And what if [I]433-i do n't always sit round here doing nothing till it strikes five up at [the church]161-the church ? Who cares if [the library]240-the library 's open or shut ? Do [you]1973-you suppose [anybody]1939-anybody ever comes [here]1923-here for books ? What [they]1939-anybody 'd like to come for is to meet [the fellows [they]1939-anybody 're going with]1981-the fellows they 're going with if [I]433-i 'd let ['em]1982-'em . Tremors of rage were running through [her]433-i , and [she]433-i steadied [herself]433-i against the edge of the desk lest [he]434-you should see [her]433-i weakness . Apparently something disagreeable has happened , for which [you]434-you think [I]433-i 'm to blame . But [I]433-i do n't know what it is , because [I]433-i 've been up on [Eagle Ridge]22-eagle ridge ever since the early morning . ”[433-i] “ [I]91-young harney do n't know where [you]434-you 've been this morning , but [I]91-young harney know [you]434-you were here in [this library]1985-this library yesterday ; and it was [you]434-you that went [home]342-home and told [[your]434-you cousin]1987-your cousin the books were in bad shape , and brought [her]1987-your cousin round to see how [I]91-young harney 'd neglected them . ”[91-young harney] [Young Harney]91-young harney looked sincerely concerned . “ Was that what [you]434-you were told ? [I]91-young harney do n't wonder [you]434-you 're angry . The books are in bad shape , and as some are interesting it 's a pity . [I]91-young harney told [Miss Hatchard]66-miss hatchard [they]1988-they were suffering from dampness and lack of air ; and [I]91-young harney brought [her]66-miss hatchard [here]1923-here to show [her]66-miss hatchard how easily [the place]154-the place could be ventilated . If [you]434-you were given a wrong version of what [I]91-young harney said [I]91-young harney 'm sorry ; but [I]91-young harney 'm so fond of old books that [I]91-young harney 'd rather see them made into a bonfire than left to moulder away like these . ”[91-young harney] [Charity]69-charity felt [her]69-charity sobs rising and tried to stifle them in words . “ [I]69-charity do n't care what [you]434-you say [you]434-you told [her]66-miss hatchard . All [I]69-charity know is [she]66-miss hatchard thinks it 's all [my]69-charity fault , and [I]69-charity 'm going to lose [my]69-charity job , and [I]69-charity wanted it more'n [[anyone]260-anyone in [the village]148-the village]1993-anyone in the village , because [I]69-charity have n't got [anybody]1939-anybody belonging to [me]69-charity , the way [other folks]1953-other folks have .
